title: Great Place To Work
pros: Great environment. Interesting projects. I look forward to coming to work.
cons: None that I can think of.

title: Smoke and Mirrors... be careful
pros: There weren't too many things I liked about the organization other than meeting some cool people. The bright minds tended to be younger and most often would leave eventually. The salary was competitive... but benefits were pretty meh.
cons: Probably the most bizarre place I've ever worked. The constant stress of project deadlines that were deemed urgent, micro-managers and directors, executives being extremely toxic and overall just a weird sense of everyone being on edge at all times. They say they care about employee well being, but in the end most of the people that stay for more than a few years are just 'yes' people who play the corporate game. Most of the bright young minds leave after a few years (rightfully so) I often had to bite my tongue in response to how my manager and director would speak to me when something wasn't working as expected. The WFH is a joke.. they say 6 days a month but that comes with caveats... no 2 days in a row, has to have manager approval, can't come before a holiday or after a weekend... it wasn't flexible at all. Additionally, every team is extremely under-staffed... the amount of project requests that would come in.. the team I worked within never had enough time to complete anything with real quality, as it was a mad rush to get it out the door. The firm was extremely wary of hiring more people, yet executive level salaries were insane... just food for thought. Unless you are unemployed or have no other job prospects, I'd carefully consider other opportunities. Obviously everyone's experience is different.. but in a nutshell this was the worst place I ever worked at (my perspective)

title: Good Entry Level Job
pros: Benefits are (were) the best I've experienced in the industry. Plus it's cool to say you work for the company that owns the "world's most famous building".
cons: So, I've had the privilege of working at a worse company and a company on par with (or a little better than) ESRT. If you're right out of college, looking for an entry level property management job to spend a couple of years at to get your resume going (because you will not get promoted, not matter how good you are. Rewarding good work or hiring from within is not their jam) you could do worse. The benefits are really good, actually. Although, they changed their bonus structure in order to deny or lower bonuses arbitrarily and they switched their insurance to a lower quality one right as I left, so I can't speak to how the benefits are now. Bottom line--you have to remember that this is a corporation in AMERICA, of all places. They don't care about you beyond if you're losing or making them money, no matter how many free bagel days or lunches they give you. At the end of the day, they will sell your building to make a buck and kick you to the curb with a backdated termination letter (so that they don't have to pay for your insurance, of course), a callous denial of severance (even though they gave all other buildings severance before you), and not even a thank you or goodbye meal (upper management didn't even email the people whose lives they were upending despite knowing them for 10+ years), whether you've worked there for 2 years or 20. In fact, you're probably treated better if you've only been there for 2 years because the CEO or whatever his nepo baby title is has some kind of obsession with Gen Z and doesn't respect lifers. And everyone is TERRIFIED of him so no one will fight on your behalf if they risk going against him. So, yeah. It's a fine place to work if you don't expect to get a lot out of it. You get good experience and meet good people but you'll most likely get stuck in your position with no hope of upward mobility.

title: Great Place to work
pros: Has been a great experience since the day I started. Team was always very welcoming and willing to help where needed.
cons: Nothing at this time to write on.

title: Toxic Manager
pros: Good Company benefits and salary
cons: bad management and no room for learning

title: Avoid
pros: You will never be fired.
cons: Idiots and sexist idiots. Kickbacks.

title: Great Culture
pros: progressive culture that is ahead of the curve in the real estate industry
cons: competing priorities are at times difficult to manage

title: Great place to work
pros: Great place to work at
cons: Sometimes there's alot of projects to work on

title: Been a while since I’ve liked where I’ve worked
pros: Team is incredible to work with and they all work incredibly hard. Happy to wake up and come in daily.
cons: Very busy. Delays in process seem fairly common. They are working towards fixing from what I’ve seen

title: Toxic
pros: WFH once a week is a plus here.
cons: Toxic, no good managers lazy employees.

title: Love all aspects of working here
pros: Colleagues, meaningful work, engaging/positive culture
cons: Sometimes it can be fast paced

title: Don't Work Here
pros: A lot of great people. Progressive in a few areas.
cons: A bad experience. Many unhappy employees both past and present. Staff sees how some are treated and know it could be them some day. They really don't care about you and will use you until they are done with you. Don't be fooled by their facade.

title: Good company culture
pros:
Competitive salary
Good company culture
cons:
Very “corporate” structure system. 
Very busy

title: Not Great
pros: Good benefits and salary/compensation. Hybrid work schedule.
cons: Very strict. Micromanaged. Felt like there was a lack of trust between employees and managers. Some employees were hourly when they should be salary.

title: Great Company, Bad Management
pros: Great work benefits. Met a lot of excellent people here.
cons: IT Management was terrible. Constantly heard upper management screaming on the phone. Unreasonable deadlines for employees. Consistently expect you to work unpaid overtime or else face consequences. Saw multiple people quit while I was here.

title: Good
pros: Good good good good good
cons: Hours all over the place

title: A good place to work
pros: great culture, progressive environment, good pay, good growth opportunity
cons: work life balance, hours, flexibility

title: Smoke and Mirrors
pros: Salary was better than other companies
cons: Not a diverse workplace or psychologically safe workplace.

title: Employee Review
pros: Landmark building. Great for a resume.
cons: No boundaries, no work/life balance, time is not respected, hard work is not appreciated, lots of blaming/finger pointing, zero support. Some teams have a big turnover for these reasons. You may have events and work 14+ days in a row. They do not give any additional time off in return. They offer a work from home policy, but working from home is frowned upon and not allowed on all teams.

title: Great Team, Great Leadership, Great Company
pros: The top level executives here listen to the employees and their concerns. Since joining the company about 4 years ago, I have watched our culture continuously improve. We are getting better and better and headed for great things. The core team here has some of the best individuals I have met over the course of my entire career- kind, loyal, dedicated and hard-working. We genuinely care about one another and help each other succeed.
cons: The environment can be fast- paced and stressful but this is not particular to the company- this is the real estate industry in general. We have many policies and protocols in place which can sometimes bog us down but overtime, I have watched us streamline our processes and consistently look for ways to improve. This is merely part of being a relatively new company establishing its best practices. The pro here is that management constantly seeks feedback and we all have a voice in shaping these policies.

title: Onward and Upward and Right Off The Top of the Rock
pros: Beautiful Historical Building Awesome part of Manhattan to spend the pre and post work hours Close numerous happy hours that help forget the mickey mouse operation that is ESRT (If they even let you out on time)
cons: Working here is like riding a bicycle. Except the bicycle is on fire, and you're on fire, and you're in hell. If you should be so fortunate to prove your worth on the job, prepare for the higher ups to serve you a buffet of inefficiency, incompetence, and ineffective management skills. If you can handle that, management may further ask you to unhinge your jaw and swallow a heaping plateful of responsibilities that you will get 0 credit for (but 100% of the blame if failed) and an all day special of empty promises. If I knew what I was getting myself into, I would've just thrown my body into traffic knowing that NYPD and the DoT would be able to take care of my corpse better than ESRT with my career.

title: Not worth the space on my resume.
pros: Basically, it sounds great to colleagues and ex-coworkers when you mention you work at the Empire State Building. There are tons of great retail stores and places to eat in the area.
cons: They have unrealistic expectations of the work to be performed. Management sets double standards for certain employees. All the executives do what they want when they want and you may get two different conflicting orders from two different executives. Even as a salary based paid employee, we are required to be tracked using a fingerprint scanner. Some departments are no help and you are blamed for work not completing on time or incorrectly done. The benefits are the worst I have ever had the "pleasure" of using. Asking for time off, you may be talked down to as if you are a 2 year old child be scolded for not going to the potty. When you mention this to someone in HR that you thought would help, nothing happens. Management and HR seems to ignore the problem because to them the issue is always with the lower level employees. No wonder a lot of people come and go through my department.

title: The Worst of the Worst
pros: It's almost over and I am finally moving on after 7 long years...
cons: Everything! Senior Management is horrible. They treat employees like pawns in a chess game, play favorites, if you are not a part of the inner circle, good luck getting a fair and decent pay increase or bonus. Stock options are not give to all employees but rather only those deemed by senior management to be "worth the investment". When employees ask “who qualifies for stock options?”, no one can give a straight answer. The HR department is the most unprofessional I have experienced in my 10+ career in real-estate industry. Incompetent, incapable, and completely useless. The HR department experienced nearly 100% turnover since 2015. Everyone with talent in that department left. Pay increases, bonuses and payroll is horrendous and run by an incompetent manager. There is a huge lack of union and employee knowledge within the HR department. As for the Operations and Finance Departments, they will work you 90+ hours a week and it’s still never good enough. Increases and bonuses are laughable in comparison to the hours worked. This has to be the worst REIT to work for. If I could rate them negative stars I would.

title: ESRT
pros: - Annual bonus (probably will be done away with for a while due to COVID - Each employee gets a free pass to the Observatory - Nice office space - Some really great people
cons: - Toxic environment - CEO runs the place like a dictator - It's a old boys club so women are not treated fairly. - Preferential treatment across the board - ESRT does not value talent and they have lost some really good people because the CEO doesn't care about anyone - They also do not pay fairly. The reward upper management handsomely but those who really do the work are not paid their worth - Inflated leadership team - Employees are fearful of the CEO and his arbitrary moods - Located in a bad area of Herald SQ. Extremely congested normally and a large homeless population.

title: King Kong with an Ego to match
pros: Agree that the company's talent at the mid and entry level is a huge asset.
cons: Thought IPO would transform the company into new thought leadership and direction. Not so. Guiding principles are more dictatorship than motivational. Cliche phrases used by top management have the opposite effect. Stop hiring friends as consultants to "expose" what's wrong with the company, instead ask for anonymous internal feedback and then don't retaliate if its not positive. Fear instilled in every employee with Jekyll and Hyde tactics. No ethics to speak of, the difference between what is right and wrong does not exist. Good hard working new employees burn out quick and start to be brainwashed into puppets and nobody can speak their minds on business concepts or direction that defies the leadership.

title: It’s the Tower of Terror
pros: The union pay and benefits
cons: Cynical, tyrannical, malevolent. I used to like this job. But now...? Everyone is miserable. Top to bottom. You’ve got a New York City land lord who behaves like Stalin but thinks he’s Walt Disney. Maybe he realizes he spent WAY too much money on “improvements “ and needs a scapegoat. Hospitality? If you’re interested in a career in hospitality avoid the Empire State Building. It isn’t about hospitality. It’s a real estate company. This is an awful place. I’m doing everything I can to get out. Everyone I know there is looking for a different job. I’ve never seen anything like it. I wouldn’t let a friend work here. It is a truly unhealthy horrible environment to work in. They believe that a frightened and unhappy staff is more easily managed. Their contempt for the staff isnt even concealed. To them I’m just an overpaid Neanderthal. It’s a mean spirited place. Avoid.

title: Awesome Company
pros: In my own experience I have found ESRT to be an under standing and enjoyable place to work. Almost all the employees enjoy their jobs and it shows in the work that is produced. It's rare that you have to work long hours and when you do it is generally recognized. I would say this is definitely a company that you can achieve a healthy work life balance at without sacrificing your career.
cons: Occasionally there is a disconnect between what would be best for the company and employees and what the actual company policies are. More flexibility for employees (work from home, no time clock, etc.) would result in higher productivity.

title: Needs work
pros: Great coworkers and decent pay and bonus.
cons: Senior leadership is reactive rather than proactive and have created an echo chamber of negativity. Be prepared to hear about the things you do wrong and none of the things you do right. This is an oppressive work atmosphere with a top down management style. Senior leadership generally does not interact with front line teams and does not understand that this is a hospitality organization that needs to run on kindness. You need to reap what you sow.

title: Depends on what you're looking for.....
pros: If you prefer a monotonous repetitive work environment this is the place for you. However, there are some great hardworking people here in various departments who have a lot to offer.
cons: If you are looking for an innovative company with opportunity for advancement LOOK ELSEWHERE. The egos of micro managers stifle performance and overall employee happiness. There has been high turnover here especially during the IPO transition. The merging of management styles between portfolio properties created an imbalance in company culture, clash of egos, and an overall mess.

title: Focused and growing company with great people
pros: Great people, location, prestige and learning experience. There's been a lot of internal growth in all departments, especially this year. Excellent benefits and compensation package. High energy and very talented coworkers, and managers are genuinely interested in their employees' growth.
cons: The 401k match is low, somewhat big egos from senior leaders, no stock options for employees, no rollover vacation, NO FLEXIBILITY

title: Happy to be here
pros: I began my journey with ESRT during COVID-19. The company has done a remarkable job with my onboarding and engagement during an impossible time. I am appreciative of how welcoming colleagues were - even while I was meeting them virtually. The company is full of hard working individuals who are very passionate about their work. We have been on partial in-office and remote work and the company has gone above and beyond to make employees feel safe while back in the office. I am happy to be a part of this team and continue to learn more about the industry daily.
cons: I do not have any to currently share.

title: Image but no substance
pros: Great people work here....but not in high positions
cons: See below (you'll see what I mean)

title: Once right, Keep It Moving, Onward and Upward.
pros: If you want to hear "once right" and "onward and upward" 600 times a day while being verbally assaulted by senior management then look no further than ESRT. Generous severance packages depending on if you're liked or if the company is afraid you will sue when you leave.
cons: Zero growth, horrible management, verbal assaults by the CEO in front of peers. Females are under represented among senior management and are disrespected and mistreated. Requirements to succeed - Age 50+, Caucasian, willing to play puppet, and lack of common sense with a scent of entitlement.

title: IT Security Manager
pros: Company is on the move and seem to care about their employees. Great social activities and expect to have a good time with ESRT employees. If your looking to move along in a fast paced company this may be your calling. If you are lucky enough you might even have a chance to work with the great people in accounting, or with such leaders as Christopher Blackman, Ryan Klass, Keith Cody, Shanae Urisini, Rodney Gomes, or the amazing Tom Keltner. Tom, had to be one of the most amazing people I have ever worked with. You will work hard at ESRT, but your day will go fast.
cons: Retirement allocations / options / company match is below what most companies contribute today, or at least what ESRT competitors match. The ESRT Retirement program desperately needs a revamp which will help the avg paid employee. However, a bonus might make up the difference if (underline if) you happen to be in the right level position. So keep that in mind if you are not a manager/director. Use of personal credit card No Remote access / Work from home policy

title: Growth In the Right Direction
pros: I've been with ESRT for about a year now, serving in a variety of different capacities that have allowed me to witness multiple facets of what it's like to be an employee here. In my experience, there are two pros that stand out the most that have made it a great place to work for me: 1. A Challenging Environment - As mentioned in some of the other reviews here, when you put yourself out there at ESRT, you are rewarded with increasing professional and educational opportunities. I have found that management has consistently challenged me to go above and beyond and learn new things in my professional life. I've been given the opportunity to take great initiative on projects despite not being here for that long, simply because I've spoken up about wanting to be more involved. There are many opportunities for growth here at ESRT and professional improvement is actively encouraged by management. I have yet to be bored here. Obviously, this can vary by department, but I can say that I have been met with overwhelming support and encouragement from management in my department to grow professionally since I started here. 2. Increasingly Receptive Management - I have played witness to a good amount of institutional change here over the last year, all of which has ultimately been very encouraging to see as an employee. Management has been making an increasing effort to listen and respond to the concerns and desires of employees, which has manifested in a steadily growing number of "office perks" and the founding of a Culture Committee, as well as a general feeling of an overall culture shift within the organization as management learns to be a bit more relaxed and open to trying new things. Within the span of a year, I feel like management has gone from being very stuffy, close-minded, and out-of-touch to really being in touch with employees and actively engaged in finding new ways to improve the experience of working here at ESRT, which has been great to see and very reassuring. Aside from the aforementioned, I have also had a very positive experience with the work environment itself, and the people who work here. The job respects a work-life balance, the people are incredibly friendly and passionate about what they do, and the office itself is very upscale and conducive to collaboration and interaction among employees. I really do enjoy coming here every day!
cons: Despite its recent progress, the organization is still very reliant on a top-down style of management which has allowed a very bureaucratic environment to thrive. My main frustrations with working here stem from: 1. A Heavy Dependence on Email - My inbox is inundated around the clock thanks to a culture of reliance on email as a primary mode of communication. Slack is not a universally-used application in our office, nor do we use any other sort of IM service for communication. I think this is definitely something that could be improved on in order to reduce inbox clutter and increase efficiency. 2. Lengthy Approval Processes - As I said above, the bureaucracy of the organization is most apparent when trying to accomplish tasks that require several levels of approval. It is understandable to have procedures in place to reduce the company's liability, however there is a such thing as too much. It is not uncommon to spend a great amount of time on a project only for it to be stymied by lengthy approval processes.

title: Good Pay / Bad Vibes
pros: Great pay and benefits package
cons: Hosts are undervalued and treated as replaceable. There aren’t any options for progression. All supervisors are sourced out - meaning most don’t have the knowledge that a lot of the staff have. The building is frustrating and inefficient. There are no women in supervisor positions. There is a “boys club” atmosphere where men frequently talk about the attractiveness of the female guests and employees. They’ve used derogatory terms to refer to female guests and employees.

title: Senior level employee
pros: Excellent working environment, employees are motivated, senior level employees are very competent and provide excellent guidance to their subordinates. Company is very considerate of its employees' needs and is responsive. Very good company to work for.
cons: It may take a little time to get used to our our open office space (for those who have previously not worked in that type of office). However, the ease of interaction with colleagues and our modern office space including conference rooms far outweighs any period of acclimatization.

title: The worst company you’ll ever work for
pros: Great colleagues that are some of the best in the industry
cons: Insane top down management style. Does not treat employees like people and spends more time trying to punish employees rather than help them succeed in their positions. You can do hundreds of good things and be excellent at your job, but one slip up could cost you your job without any other considerations. A constant feeling of walking on eggshells, 11th hour decisions from upper management, and a serious lack of direction.

title: Great place to work
pros: Loved working at ESRT, it’s a great place to learn. Everyone is always willing and happy to teach/mentor if you’re willing to learn. Senior management has done a lot to improve the culture and seems to truly care about their employees through the implementation of various programs like flex work, flex fridays, enhanced benefits.. etc Had a great experience here and would recommend the company to all.
cons: Difficult to grow quickly must be willing to be patient

title: Sucks the life out of you
pros: It's really cool to work for the owners of the Empire State Building. Great networking opportunities. Great name for resume.
cons: Sucks the life out of you. Expected to work 'round the clock. Overworked and underpaid. Increased workload every year and have to beg for a decent raise. Low company morale. High turnover.

title: Good people but bad management!
pros: Really nice people! The people you work with are the best thing about being employed at ESRT.
cons: Management is not really flexible. Moving up is a rare thing at ESRT if you do you must be a favorite or a money maker but it takes everyone to make a company run not just a select few.

title: Onward and Upward
pros: Over the past few years, I've seen a shift in management for the better. They are implementing changes to display their appreciation for their employees. While no company is perfect, ESRT is aiming to provide a welcoming and more productive workplace. -Mgmt challenges you to become more well rounded and build upon your skills by taking courses and joining committees. -Newly implemented initiatives have brought up company morale: Casual Days, Gratitude Fridays, and Flex/Summer Fridays.
cons: -No work-from-home program -Lengthy Approval Processes

title: Great Place to Learn from the Best and Contribute!
pros: A forward-thinking, highly-successful company comprised of the industry's leading experts and foremost professionals. Passionate, caring and hard-working staff who strive for excellence. Collaborative, creative work environment.
cons: Requires high-level skill set and strong work ethic to succeed--which is not a negative if you are willing to work hard and contribute unique value.

title: Tyrannical Totalitarianism at its Best!
pros: Culture, what culture? If tyrannical totalitarianism is the culture you are striving for, this is the company to work for! The individuals working at the Empire State Building and its Observatory are some of the most talented professionals in the industry. Their other properties... not so much.
cons: HR, like most professions, values ethical principles. People are the most important asset of an organization but also its biggest potential liability. One would assume that HR is ethically responsible for promoting and fostering fairness and justice for all employees throughout the organization; however, ESRT’s disparate, discriminatory, and retaliatory practices make HR’s position within the organization obsolete. The greatest liabilities in the organization are the individuals in charge of running it. The top-heavy tyrannical executive office is compiled of “bosses” not “leaders” (all of whom hate each other and refuse to communicate with each other). As Human Capital professionals and culture champions, you know something is deeply wrong with an organization when 80% of the HR department leaves in 6 months to go work for the company’s biggest competitors. The executive office chalks employee resignations up to those resigning as being “bad employees”. If resignations were coming from “bad employees”, I doubt your competitors would be hiring them at double their salaries. When resigning, expect to get shunned from senior management. It is pointless to put in 2 weeks’ notice. During the notice period, not a single person on the senior management team acknowledges your existence. My advice to existing staff is – Get out while you still have what’s left of your morals and dignity. Competitors are looking for your talent and are willing to equitability compensate you for it. My advice to prospective employees is – Unless you’re taking a position making $300K+ a year, its best to keep it moving. Even at $300K a year, employees are dropping like flies.

title: Hypocritical management that creates a borderline toxic environment
pros: Environmentally
cons: cious, the OBS is cool, there are some decent projects if you're lucky

title: Happy To have left
pros: You will gain a lot of experience here as they throw many projects and assignments at their staff. You will also develop tough skin.
cons: Management places unrealistic expectations on staff with limited or no direction. They are constantly under staffed which leads to a tense work environment.

title: Tenant Services Coordinator
pros: Reality of this workplace? Better off playing in traffic if you don't have a family to feed.
cons: No one has your back, office morale...nil. Hopefully their investors get wind of the brutal dictatorship & horrible management skills because it's all a farse & a sham bunch of cover-up activity to make this once respected family business a modern day slavery ship full of brown nosers.

title: Great Company
pros: Empire State Realty Trust (ESRT) is a great company. I am thankful to be a part of a company that supports me, guides me, and allows me to implement my charitable ideas through our ESRT Volunteer Committee.
cons: No cons at this time.

title: Good learning experience
pros: Pays really well. And after certain amount of years, you gain 3 weeks vacation.
cons: You aren’t able to grow in the company. Most people who work there aren’t happy. They dont look at the positive side of things. Management doesn’t really care about you.

title: "Great Company"
pros: I had a great experience working at Empire State Realty Trust. The culture was very strong. My coworkers were very friendly and made coming to work each day fun and rewarding. I was able to work on a variety of interesting projects throughout my time at ESRT and learned from some of the most knowledgeable professionals in the industry. I would highly recommend working here.
cons: Not applicable to my experience.

title: Must be extremely hard working
pros: Some of the smartest and hardest working people work here, great new office, lots of additional perks if you work in certain departments, great pay
cons: Upper management does not really care about employee work/life balance. The bar is set extremely high for performance, often without any room for mistakes.

title: Stay
pros: The guests; Majority of them are very nice and it feels good to share the Experience with them. The Pay is decent to good depends on the person.
cons: Almost EVERYTHING THERE IS A CON. POOR MANAGEMENT ( some needs training and some would be better off elsewhere in the Fast Food Industry) LACK OF COMMUNICATION, MEDIEVAL RULES ( make you feel less human, there is a write up for almost everything: Adults wearing pants with no pockets, and they told you is because staff tends to put their hands inside meanwhile a supervisor walking by with a baby Mohawk hair cut. Some of the female supervisors need to be dressed more appropriate to the company standard no sneakers or Huggs boots (maybe on a snow day) and show the guests that they CARE because they are asking us but they are not doing it. BASICALLY ALL THE COMPANY CARES ABOUT IS TAKING THE GUESTS MONEY. UNDER-STAFF you have a 120 mins waiting time and you expect one host to do 3 hosts jobs in return your TRIP ADVISOR reviews will not be what you expected it to be but then again you surprised with the results and Blamed the Hosts when you should have hired or scheduled more people. One more thing is sometime you have a host spending the entire day there from early on until closing 2 AM after when scientifically proven after 12 hours the human brain is totally disconnected and is just on ROBOTIC MODE. Then you have the nerve to tell the hosts not to sound like a robot. The Employee are not set up to SUCCEED, they are set up to fail. January weather forecast 9 degrees windshield in minus you have a guard out in front with all face covered totally ridiculous. FAMILY MEMBER WORKING IN MANAGEMENT AND COVERING FOR EACH OTHER.

title: Fantastic Year to Be an ESRT Employee
pros: In the past year, this company has truly taken huge strides in creating a happier, more enjoyable work environment for its employees. You can tell that management is listening and working to boost morale and company culture.
cons: Weak 401k Match - this should be much better!

title: Great Company!
pros: The company is very supportive with their employees, upper management encourages and values employee feedback. When issues or concerns are brought to HR or upper management's attention-they are addressed.
cons: Negativity among a few employees who don't realize that they are working for a good company and that you get what you put into it.

title: Fun and Easy Customer Service Position
pros: The work is simple and only stressful if you allow yourself to lose your patience. If you remember everyone is visiting to have a good time and your job is to add to their positive experience, than the job is rewarding!
cons: Standing the entire shift. Little is done to make employees feel appreciated. No upward mobility.

title: Good Company
pros: A forward-thinking company that challenges staff to learn and excel in their positions by giving them opportunities to enhance their skills. Interesting projects that keep the job exciting.
cons: Senior management needs to be diversified. More flexibility.

title: Great place to learn from the best and brightest in the industry
pros: Management rewards those who show grit, determination, and a constant desire to improve the results of their team. Plenty of opportunities to pitch in across multiple departments and learn new skills.
cons: No vending machines in the break room.

title: Trust your employees
pros: Amazing opportunity to showcase a landmark building on the resume.
cons: Micromanagement No trust in employee input Too much emphasis on unimportant things and not enough on what matters most

title: Not thee best place to work
pros: This company has good benefits and can be a great company to work for of management changes.
cons: No organization, Horrible training, No professionalism in the office including HR

title: Challenging to say least.
pros: Some great employees work very hard consistently.
cons: Hr doesn't address the concerns of racism and toxic people when you go to them numerous times. But the truth always comes to light sooner or later.

title: Great Place to Work!
pros: ESRT recognizes and rewards those who are positive contributors in delivering quality service to our tenants and guests. Great collaboration amongst teams/departments.
cons: No downside. Those individuals that are negative need to get off the train!

title: You have been warned.
pros: I have no pros regarding this company. You will receive basic benefits and be expected to put work before your family and personal life. Your efforts will not be rewarded.
cons: Very high turn around rate. Employee's are fired weekly. Everyone is living in fear of the Senior Management. This is a Shark Tank. You have been warned.

title: .NET Software Developer / Programmer
pros: The culture is amazing. Everyone is friendly. When doing team work with my manager, putting our minds together, sky is the limit.
cons: I made a hard attempt at finding one, and came up with absolutely nothing.

title: Definitely Recommend
pros: The first company where I have felt valued and appreciated. There is definitely room for growth as long as the work is put in.
cons: The occasional work from home would be great.

title: It has it's ups and downs
pros: great working with colleagues, benefits are great as well. Hours not so bad either.
cons: This is an At Will Employment, some good people have come and gone. if you can tough it out, then this is the job for you.

title: Solid job. Great work life balance and excellent bonus and benefits.

title: Unprofessional

title: Not a place I would recommend
